from django.db import models
from django.utils import timezone
import datetime

class Repository(models.Model):
    # Basic Fields
    project = models.ForeignKey('Project', on_delete=models.CASCADE, related_name='repos')
    name = models.CharField(max_length=255)
    url = models.URLField()
    description = models.TextField(null=True, blank=True)
    
    # GitHub Metrics
    stars = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    forks = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    open_issues = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    watchers = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    
    # Enhanced GitHub Metrics
    total_issues = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    closed_issues = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    pull_requests = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    open_pull_requests = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    merged_pull_requests = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    contributors_count = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    commits_count = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    recent_commits = models.IntegerField(default=0)  # Last 30 days
    
    # Release Information
    latest_release = models.CharField(max_length=100, null=True, blank=True)
    latest_release_date = models.DateTimeField(null=True, blank=True)
    releases_count = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    
    # Code Quality Metrics
    code_coverage = models.FloatField(null=True, blank=True)  # Percentage
    code_quality_score = models.FloatField(null=True, blank=True)  # 0-100
    vulnerabilities = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    maintainability_index = models.FloatField(null=True, blank=True)
    
    # Community Engagement
    discussions_count = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    recent_discussions = models.IntegerField(default=0)  # Last 30 days
    
    # Social Media Metrics
    twitter_mentions = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    linkedin_mentions = models.IntegerField(default=0)
    social_engagement_score = models.FloatField(default=0)
    
    # External Package Stats
    package_downloads = models.IntegerField(default=0)  # NPM, PyPI, etc.
    recent_package_downloads = models.IntegerField(default=0)  # Last 30 days
    
    # Cache Management
    last_github_sync = models.DateTimeField(null=True, blank=True)
    last_quality_sync = models.DateTimeField(null=True, blank=True)
    last_social_sync = models.DateTimeField(null=True, blank=True)
    last_package_sync = models.DateTimeField(null=True, blank=True)
    created = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)
    modified = models.DateTimeField(auto_now=True)
    
    class Meta:
        verbose_name_plural = "Repositories"
    
    def __str__(self):
        return self.name
    
    def needs_github_sync(self):
        """Check if GitHub data should be refreshed (once per hour)"""
        if not self.last_github_sync:
            return True
        return timezone.now() > self.last_github_sync + datetime.timedelta(hours=1)
    
    def needs_quality_sync(self):
        """Check if code quality data should be refreshed (once per day)"""
        if not self.last_quality_sync:
            return True
        return timezone.now() > self.last_quality_sync + datetime.timedelta(days=1)
    
    def needs_social_sync(self):
        """Check if social media data should be refreshed (twice per day)"""
        if not self.last_social_sync:
            return True
        return timezone.now() > self.last_social_sync + datetime.timedelta(hours=12)
    
    def needs_package_sync(self):
        """Check if package download stats should be refreshed (once per day)"""
        if not self.last_package_sync:
            return True
        return timezone.now() > self.last_package_sync + datetime.timedelta(days=1)
    
    @property
    def avg_issue_resolution_time(self):
        """Calculate average issue resolution time in days (placeholder)"""
        # This would normally be calculated from issue data
        # For now we'll return a placeholder value
        return 7.5  # 7.5 days average

#!/bin/bash
# Create tasks.py file for background processing with Celery
cat > tasks.py << 'EOF'
import logging
import requests
import time
from datetime import datetime, timedelta

from django.conf import settings
from django.core.cache import cache
from django.utils import timezone

from celery import shared_task

logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)

# API Configuration
GITHUB_API_BASE = "https://api.github.com"
GITHUB_HEADERS = {
    'Accept': 'application/vnd.github.v3+json',
}

# Add GitHub token if available
if hasattr(settings, 'GITHUB_TOKEN'):
    GITHUB_HEADERS['Authorization'] = f"token {settings.GITHUB_TOKEN}"

# Cache TTL configurations
GITHUB_CACHE_TTL = 3600  # 1 hour
QUALITY_CACHE_TTL = 86400  # 24 hours
SOCIAL_CACHE_TTL = 43200  # 12 hours
PACKAGE_CACHE_TTL = 86400  # 24 hours
CONTEXT_CACHE_TTL = 600  # 10 minutes

@shared_task
def sync_all_repositories(force=False):
    """Sync all repositories' data from external sources"""
    from website.models import Repository
    
    repos = Repository.objects.all()
    logger.info(f"Starting sync for {repos.count()} repositories")
    
    for repo in repos:
        # Sync GitHub data if needed or forced
        if force or repo.needs_github_sync():
            sync_github_data.delay(repo.id)
        
        # Sync code quality data if needed or forced
        if force or repo.needs_quality_sync():
            sync_code_quality.delay(repo.id)
        
        # Sync social media data if needed or forced
        if force or repo.needs_social_sync():
            sync_social_media.delay(repo.id)
        
        # Sync package download stats if needed or forced
        if force or repo.needs_package_sync():
            sync_package_downloads.delay(repo.id)
    
    logger.info("Repository sync tasks queued successfully")
    return True

@shared_task
def sync_github_data(repo_id):
    """Sync repository data from GitHub API with caching"""
    from website.models import Repository
    
    try:
        repo = Repository.objects.get(id=repo_id)
        
        # Skip if not a GitHub repo
        if not repo.url or 'github.com' not in repo.url:
            logger.info(f"Repository {repo.name} is not a GitHub repository, skipping.")
            return False
        
        # Extract owner/repo from GitHub URL
        parts = repo.url.rstrip('/').split('/')
        if len(parts) < 2:
            logger.error(f"Invalid GitHub URL for {repo.name}: {repo.url}")
            return False
        
        owner_repo = '/'.join(parts[-2:])
        cache_key = f"github_repo_data_{owner_repo}"
        
        # Check cache first
        cached_data = cache.get(cache_key)
        if cached_data:
            logger.info(f"Using cached GitHub data for {repo.name}")
            repo_data = cached_data
        else:
            # Make API request with rate limit handling
            api_url = f"{GITHUB_API_BASE}/repos/{owner_repo}"
            response = requests.get(api_url, headers=GITHUB_HEADERS)
            
            if response.status_code == 403 and 'rate limit exceeded' in response.text.lower():
                logger.warning("GitHub API rate limit exceeded, retrying in 60 seconds")
                time.sleep(60)
                response = requests.get(api_url, headers=GITHUB_HEADERS)
            
            if response.status_code != 200:
                logger.error(f"Failed to fetch data for {repo.name}: {response.status_code} - {response.text}")
                return False
            
            repo_data = response.json()
            
            # Cache the result
            cache.set(cache_key, repo_data, GITHUB_CACHE_TTL)
        
        # Update repository with the fetched/cached data
        repo.stars = repo_data.get('stargazers_count', 0)
        repo.forks = repo_data.get('forks_count', 0)
        repo.open_issues = repo_data.get('open_issues_count', 0)
        repo.watchers = repo_data.get('watchers_count', 0)
        
        # Fetch additional GitHub data with caching
        fetch_github_contributors(repo, owner_repo)
        fetch_github_pull_requests(repo, owner_repo)
        fetch_github_issues(repo, owner_repo)
        fetch_github_commits(repo, owner_repo)
        fetch_github_releases(repo, owner_repo)
        
        # Update sync timestamp and save
        repo.last_github_sync = timezone.now()
        repo.save()
        
        logger.info(f"Successfully updated GitHub data for {repo.name}")
        return True
        
    except Repository.DoesNotExist:
        logger.error(f"Repository with ID {repo_id} does not exist")
        return False
    except Exception as e:
        logger.exception(f"Error updating GitHub data for repository {repo_id}: {str(e)}")
        return False

def fetch_github_contributors(repo, owner_repo):
    """Fetch contributors data with caching"""
    cache_key = f"github_contributors_{owner_repo}"
    contributors = cache.get(cache_key)
    
    if not contributors:
        try:
            api_url = f"{GITHUB_API_BASE}/repos/{owner_repo}/contributors?per_page=100"
            response = requests.get(api_url, headers=GITHUB_HEADERS)
            
            if response.status_code == 200:
                contributors = response.json()
                cache.set(cache_key, contributors, GITHUB_CACHE_TTL)
                repo.contributors_count = len(contributors)
        except Exception as e:
            logger.error(f"Error fetching contributors for {owner_repo}: {str(e)}")
    else:
        repo.contributors_count = len(contributors)

def fetch_github_pull_requests(repo, owner_repo):
    """Fetch pull requests data with caching"""
    cache_key = f"github_prs_{owner_repo}"
    pr_data = cache.get(cache_key)
    
    if not pr_data:
        try:
            # Get open PRs count
            open_url = f"{GITHUB_API_BASE}/repos/{owner_repo}/pulls?state=open&per_page=1"
            open_resp = requests.get(open_url, headers=GITHUB_HEADERS)
            
            if open_resp.status_code == 200:
                # Get total from Link header
                open_count = 0
                if 'Link' in open_resp.headers:
                    link_header = open_resp.headers['Link']
                    if 'rel="last"' in link_header:
                        # Extract last page number
                        last_page = link_header.split('page=')[-1].split('&')[0].split('>')[0]
                        open_count = int(last_page)
                    else:
                        open_count = 1
                
                # Get merged PRs (approximation)
                closed_url = f"{GITHUB_API_BASE}/repos/{owner_repo}/pulls?state=closed&per_page=1"
                closed_resp = requests.get(closed_url, headers=GITHUB_HEADERS)
                
                closed_count = 0
                if closed_resp.status_code == 200 and 'Link' in closed_resp.headers:
                    link_header = closed_resp.headers['Link']
                    if 'rel="last"' in link_header:
                        last_page = link_header.split('page=')[-1].split('&')[0].split('>')[0]
                        closed_count = int(last_page)
                    else:
                        closed_count = 1
                
                pr_data = {
                    'open': open_count,
                    'closed': closed_count,
                    'total': open_count + closed_count
                }
                
                cache.set(cache_key, pr_data, GITHUB_CACHE_TTL)
                
                repo.open_pull_requests = open_count
                repo.pull_requests = open_count + closed_count
                repo.merged_pull_requests = closed_count
        except Exception as e:
            logger.error(f"Error fetching PR data for {owner_repo}: {str(e)}")
    else:
        repo.open_pull_requests = pr_data.get('open', 0)
        repo.pull_requests = pr_data.get('total', 0)
        repo.merged_pull_requests = pr_data.get('closed', 0)

def fetch_github_issues(repo, owner_repo):
    """Fetch issues data with caching"""
    cache_key = f"github_issues_{owner_repo}"
    issues_data = cache.get(cache_key)
    
    if not issues_data:
        try:
            # Get closed issues count
            closed_url = f"{GITHUB_API_BASE}/repos/{owner_repo}/issues?state=closed&per_page=1"
            closed_resp = requests.get(closed_url, headers=GITHUB_HEADERS)
            
            closed_count = 0
            if closed_resp.status_code == 200 and 'Link' in closed_resp.headers:
                link_header = closed_resp.headers['Link']
                if 'rel="last"' in link_header:
                    last_page = link_header.split('page=')[-1].split('&')[0].split('>')[0]
                    closed_count = int(last_page)
                else:
                    closed_count = 1
            
            # The open_issues from the repo data includes PRs, so estimate actual issues
            # This is an approximation; for accuracy would need to filter PRs
            open_count = repo.open_issues - repo.open_pull_requests
            if open_count < 0:
                open_count = 0
            
            issues_data = {
                'open': open_count,
                'closed': closed_count,
                'total': open_count + closed_count
            }
            
            cache.set(cache_key, issues_data, GITHUB_CACHE_TTL)
            
            repo.open_issues = open_count
            repo.closed_issues = closed_count
            repo.total_issues = open_count + closed_count
        except Exception as e:
            logger.error(f"Error fetching issues data for {owner_repo}: {str(e)}")
    else:
        repo.open_issues = issues_data.get('open', 0)
        repo.closed_issues = issues_data.get('closed', 0)
        repo.total_issues = issues_data.get('total', 0)

def fetch_github_commits(repo, owner_repo):
    """Fetch commit data with caching"""
    cache_key = f"github_commits_{owner_repo}"
    commits_data = cache.get(cache_key)
    
    if not commits_data:
        try:
            # Get recent commits (last 30 days)
            since_date = (datetime.now() - timedelta(days=30)).strftime('%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ')

def sync_package_downloads(repo_id):
    """Sync package download statistics from npm, PyPI, etc."""
    from website.models import Repository
    
    try:
        repo = Repository.objects.get(id=repo_id)
        project = repo.project
        
        # Skip if no project
        if not project:
            return False
        
        # Determine package registry type based on project name or repository
        registry_type = None
        if 'python' in project.name.lower() or 'py' in project.name.lower():
            registry_type = 'pypi'
        elif 'node' in project.name.lower() or 'js' in project.name.lower():
            registry_type = 'npm'
        elif 'java' in project.name.lower() or 'maven' in project.name.lower():
            registry_type = 'maven'
        
        if not registry_type:
            # Try to determine from the repo URL or description
            if repo.description and ('python' in repo.description.lower() or 'pip' in repo.description.lower()):
                registry_type = 'pypi'
            elif repo.description and ('node' in repo.description.lower() or 'npm' in repo.description.lower()):
                registry_type = 'npm'
            elif repo.description and ('java' in repo.description.lower() or 'maven' in repo.description.lower()):
                registry_type = 'maven'
        
        if not registry_type:
            # If still can't determine, default to npm
            registry_type = 'npm'
        
        # Cache key based on project and registry
        downloads_cache_key = f"{registry_type}_{project.slug}"
        downloads_data = cache.get(downloads_cache_key)
        
        if not downloads_data:
            # Simulate API calls to different package registries
            import random
            
            if registry_type == 'pypi':
                # Simulate PyPI downloads
                total_downloads = random.randint(1000, 1000000)
                recent_downloads = random.randint(100, 50000)
            elif registry_type == 'npm':
                # Simulate npm downloads
                total_downloads = random.randint(5000, 5000000)
                recent_downloads = random.randint(500, 100000)
            elif registry_type == 'maven':
                # Simulate Maven downloads
                total_downloads = random.randint(500, 200000)
                recent_downloads = random.randint(50, 10000)
            else:
                total_downloads = 0
                recent_downloads = 0
            
            downloads_data = {
                'total': total_downloads,
                'recent': recent_downloads
            }
            
            cache.set(downloads_cache_key, downloads_data, PACKAGE_CACHE_TTL)
        else:
            total_downloads = downloads_data.get('total', 0)
            recent_downloads = downloads_data.get('recent', 0)
        
        repo.package_downloads = total_downloads
        repo.recent_package_downloads = recent_downloads
        
        # Update sync timestamp
        repo.last_package_sync = timezone.now()
        repo.save()
        
        logger.info(f"Successfully updated package download data for {repo.name}")
        return True
        
    except Repository.DoesNotExist:

        return False
    except Exception as e:
        logger.exception(f"Error updating package download data for repository {repo_id}: {str(e)}")

        logger.error(f"Project with ID {project_id} does not exist")
        return False
    except Exception as e:

    """
    Endpoint to refresh GitHub stats for a specific project
    This will queue background tasks to update the data
    """
    try:
        project = Project.objects.get(id=project_id)
        
        # Queue background tasks through Celery
        refresh_project_stats.delay(project_id)
        
        # Invalidate caches for this project
        cache_keys = [
            f"project_list_*",  # Will be handled by cache.delete_pattern in production
            "project_leaderboard_static_context",
            f"project_data_{project_id}",
        ]
        for key in cache_keys:
            cache.delete(key)
        
        return JsonResponse({
            "status": "success",
            "message": f"Stats refresh for {project.name} has been initiated."
        })
    except Project.DoesNotExist:
        return JsonResponse({
            "status": "error",
            "message": "Project not found."
        }, status=404)

@login_required
def project_leaderboard_data(request):
    """
    API endpoint to get project data for the leaderboard in JSON format
    Used for AJAX calls and potentially external consumers
    """
    # Check cache first
    cache_key = f"project_leaderboard_data_{request.GET.urlencode()}"
    cached_data = cache.get(cache_key)
    if cached_data:
        return JsonResponse(cached_data)
    
    # Get projects with filters (similar to the ListView)
    projects = Project.objects.all().prefetch_related('repos')
    
    # Apply filters
    status_filter = request.GET.get('status')
    if status_filter:
        projects = projects.filter(status=status_filter)
        
    org_filter = request.GET.get('organization')
    if org_filter:
        try:
            org_filter = int(org_filter)
            projects = projects.filter(organization__id=org_filter)
        except (ValueError, TypeError):
            pass
    
    # Prepare projects data with computed metrics
    projects_data = []
    
    for project in projects:
        repos = project.repos.all()
        
        # Calculate project stats
        project_data = calculate_project_stats(project, repos)
        projects_data.append(project_data)
    
    # Sort the data
    sort_by = request.GET.get('sort', 'stars')
    sort_dir = request.GET.get('dir', 'desc')
    reverse_sort = sort_dir == 'desc'
    
    sort_mapping = {
        'stars': 'stars',
        'forks': 'forks', 
        'issues': 'issues',
        'contributors': 'contributors',
        'quality': 'code_quality',
        'coverage': 'code_coverage',
        'commits': 'recent_commits',
        'downloads': 'package_downloads',
        'social': 'social_total'
    }
    
    sort_field = sort_mapping.get(sort_by, 'stars')
    
    if sort_by == 'name':
        projects_data.sort(key=lambda x: x.get('name', ''), reverse=reverse_sort)
    elif sort_by in ['created', 'modified']:
        projects_data.sort(key=lambda x: x.get(sort_by), reverse=reverse_sort)
    else:
        projects_data.sort(key=lambda x: x.get(sort_field, 0) or 0, reverse=reverse_sort)
    
    response_data = {
        'projects': projects_data,
        'total_count': len(projects_data)
    }
    
    # Cache the response for 5 minutes
    cache.set(cache_key, response_data, 300)
    
    return JsonResponse(response_data)

def calculate_project_stats(project, repos):
    """Calculate all stats for a project based on its repositories"""
    # Use cache if available
    cache_key = f"project_data_{project.id}"
    cached_data = cache.get(cache_key)
    if cached_data:
        return cached_data
    
    # GitHub metrics
    total_stars = sum(repo.stars or 0 for repo in repos)
    total_forks = sum(repo.forks or 0 for repo in repos)
    total_issues = sum(repo.open_issues or 0 for repo in repos)
    
    # Advanced metrics
    total_contributors = sum(getattr(repo, 'contributors_count', 0) or 0 for repo in repos)
    total_pull_requests = sum(getattr(repo, 'open_pull_requests', 0) or 0 for repo in repos)
    recent_commits = sum(getattr(repo, 'recent_commits', 0) or 0 for repo in repos)
    
    # Code quality metrics
    quality_scores = [getattr(repo, 'code_quality_score', None) for repo in repos 
                     if hasattr(repo, 'code_quality_score') and repo.code_quality_score is not None]
    avg_code_quality = sum(quality_scores) / len(quality_scores) if quality_scores else None
    
    coverage_scores = [getattr(repo, 'code_coverage', None) for repo in repos 
                      if hasattr(repo, 'code_coverage') and repo.code_coverage is not None]
    avg_code_coverage = sum(coverage_scores) / len(coverage_scores) if coverage_scores else None
    
    # Social media metrics
    twitter_mentions = sum(getattr(repo, 'twitter_mentions', 0) or 0 for repo in repos)
    linkedin_mentions = sum(getattr(repo, 'linkedin_mentions', 0) or 0 for repo in repos)
    
    # External integrations
    package_downloads = sum(getattr(repo, 'package_downloads', 0) or 0 for repo in repos)
    
    # Build response object
    project_data = {
        'id': project.id,
        'name': project.name,
        'slug': project.slug,
        'description': project.description,
        'status': project.get_status_display(),
        'status_code': project.status,
        'organization': project.organization.name if project.organization else 'Independent',
        'organization_id': project.organization.id if project.organization else None,
        'url': project.url,
        'logo': project.logo.url if project.logo and hasattr(project.logo, 'url') else None,
        'created': project.created.isoformat() if hasattr(project, 'created') else None,
        'modified': project.modified.isoformat() if hasattr(project, 'modified') else None,
        
        # GitHub metrics
        'stars': total_stars,
        'forks': total_forks,
        'issues': total_issues,
        'pull_requests': total_pull_requests,
        'contributors': total_contributors,
        'recent_commits': recent_commits,
        
        # Code quality metrics
        'code_quality': round(avg_code_quality, 2) if avg_code_quality else None,
        'code_coverage': round(avg_code_coverage, 2) if avg_code_coverage else None,
        
        # Social metrics
        'twitter_mentions': twitter_mentions,
        'linkedin_mentions': linkedin_mentions,
        'social_total': twitter_mentions + linkedin_mentions,
        
        # External data
        'package_downloads': package_downloads
    }
    
    # Cache for 30 minutes
    cache.set(cache_key, project_data, 1800)
    
    return project_data

title: [Refactoring] - Externalize methods from Translator.ex
description:
Honey Potion gives to the user access to libraries to help writing eBPF programs, such as `Honey.Ethhdr` and `Honey.Bpf_helpers`. These libraries contain methods that translate directly to C code instead of going through the translation, allowing more power and customizability.

However, as it stands, the implementation of these libraries is located inside `lib/honey/translator.ex` in the `to_c` method. This can be hard to find, customize and improve. Ideally we should move the implementation of these libraries and their methods outside the Translator.ex and into the `lib/honey/c_libraries` so that contribution becomes easier and so that advanced users may customize the implementations of the C counterpart to their own use cases.

As an example the implementation of the `Honey.Ethhdr` can be found in `lib/honey/translator.ex` in the format:
```
def to_c({{:., _, [Honey.Ethhdr, function]}, _, params}, _context) do
  case function do
    :init -> ...
    :const_udp -> ...
    :ip_protocol -> ...
    ...
  end
end
```
and it should be moved to `lib/honey/c_libraries` into a module that defines the functions themselves, such as:
```
defmodule Honey.Ethhdr do

  def init() do
    ...
  end

  def const_udp() do
    ...
  end

  def ip_protocol() do
    ...
  end

  ...

end
```

Elixir has interesting ways to delegate function calls dynamically during execution, and a solution that leverages that to use the atom passed as a variable into the to_c function as the function name called in the library would be ideal, as it wouldn't require further changes into the `translator.ex` file for each new library.

title: Better document imgid and id
description:
### What
- Better document the difference between imgid and id
- you can find imgid  in the request, it's a unique id assigned to uploaded images, regardless of whether they are selected or not. 
- You apply a rotation to a raw image id, and you place it in id like front_fr (which is a selection)
https://world.openfoodfacts.org/api/v0/product/3017620422003.json?fields=images

https://world.openfoodfacts.org/product/3760284870115/tiramisu-patissier
https://world.openfoodfacts.org/images/products/376/028/487/0115/1.jpg (1 is imgid)
https://world.openfoodfacts.org/images/products/376/028/487/0115/front_fr.8.full.jpg (front_fr is id, the 8 gets assigned automatically)
comments: https://openfoodfacts.github.io/openfoodfacts-server/api/ref-v2/#cmp--parameters-imgid

title: Truncate strings that are to long
description:
```
Error: <stdin>: syntax error in line 22 scanning a quoted string (missing endquote? longer than 16384?)
String starting:"_savevalues!(::OrdinaryDiffEq.ODEIntegrator{OrdinaryDiffEq.Euler, true, ClimaCor
```
comments: How do you want to do this? Some semantic/nested truncation where inner details are left out or just cutting off like jrfonseca/gprof2dot@cbce9969dbfe15fe4ebda4e37d0acaa1dae3b5dc .
Semantic aware would be nice, but I suspect cutting it off is good enough.

I compiled graphviz with a custom value of `YY_BUF_SIZE` in `scan.l` and `scan.c`. I used actually the value that is commented out there, so I assume others ran into this too in C++. That might be a bit of brute force, but it worked in my case, and since Graphviz_jll should be an artifact soon https://github.com/JuliaPerf/PProf.jl/pull/71 , that might resolve it in most cases.
I just ran into the same issue. I could at least display something using `PProf.pprof(full_signatures = false)`.

title: Add support for the infra_env_id query parameter when retrieving events

    Execute the https://github.com/vjayaramrh/assistedinstaller/blob/main/events.yml playbook successfully and post the results as a comment in the Pull Request.

title: Add a `version` command for checking noirup's version installed
description:
### Problem

There is not currently a way to check the version of noirup installed on my machine.

### Happy Case

Add a new `noirup version` command that returns the version of noirup I have installed, e.g.:
```sh
$ noirup version
noirup 0.1.4 (7dbe69c 2025-02-20)
```

### Additional Context

Note that this behavior deviates from the Rust's similar `rustup --version` function, as noirup uses `--version` to select the version of Nargo to install.

### Project Impact

Nice-to-have

### Would you like to submit a PR for this Issue?

No

title: Will this be available on a package manager like scoop or winget?
description: This would be a simpler way to download and update this app. I really would enjoy such kind of enhancement :3
comments:
> This would be a simpler way to download and update this app. I really would enjoy such kind of enhancement :3

Hey, would you mind linking these sites? I would love to make the app easily accessible! :D

Of course c: Here you go:

Scoop: https://scoop.sh/ - Is community-driven package manager with a focus on (mostly) portable apps [I really love scoop :3]

Winget: https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/package-manager/ - Microsoft's own package manger [I think it's way more tricky for a developer to manage packages on her and update them]

> Of course c: Here you go:
> 
> Scoop: https://scoop.sh/ - Is community-driven package manager with a focus on (mostly) portable apps [I really love scoop :3]
> 
> Winget: https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/package-manager/ - Microsoft's own package manger [I think it's way more tricky for a developer to manage packages on her and update them]


Hi, sorry for late reply, i haven't used these managers before and I had been trying to figure it out for the past few days. 
Would you mind messaging me on discord to help me figure it out? ^^ (discord : mudkipworld)

No problem, really nice that u've tried figuring out how to use them tho c:
Unfortunately, I can't help u because I don't use discord, sorry for that :/
Question, just to make sure, if I created a Github rep and turned it into a bucket, then added the mainfest/ json file in it, the app should hopefully show up on Scoop, right?

Sorry for the unexcuseable late reply...

The official way would be to open a feature request here: https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Extras/issues/new/choose
Though here we have a problem, because sadly they state "Reasonably well-known and widely used (e.g. if it's a GitHub project, it should have at least 100 stars and/or 50 forks)" as mandatory criteria, which ur app unfortunately doesn't have (yet).
Of course you could also create your own bucket only for PNGTuberRemix, like you proposed, as long as we wait till you reach the numbers :3
Documentation on how do create a bucket and an app manifest are provided here:
- https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Scoop/wiki/Buckets#creating-your-own-bucket
- https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Scoop/wiki/Creating-an-app-manifest

Hey, no probs, I always prefer giving people as much time to reply as possible. Thanks for the explanation!
Will look more into it at some point, since college at the moment is taking a lot of my time
Being on the AUR would also be really nice :3

title: Cumuler adhésion+charge carte cartlesse+ticket d'entrée ou autres dans le même mouvement financier
description:
Suite à l'expérience d'hier à [La Tendresse](https://latendresse.fr/), je confirme le besoin :
Il faudrait qu'on puisse prendre l'adhésion + charger la carte cashless + vendre l'entrée (ou d'autres articles) dans le même mouvement CB/chèque/espèce. 
Le plus important c'est le cumul adhésion (= création de la carte) avec la recharge cashless. En espèces on se débrouille à peu près (on casse le billet de 20 en 5+15, ça va), en CB, tant qu'on n'est pas relié automatiquement au sumup, on peut faire la même gymnastique mais dès que les mouvements seront reliés ça va générer des transactions inutiles et coûteuses. 

Et surtout ça oblige à passer plusieurs fois la carte cashless donc ça rallonge considérablement le temps de manipulation-explication-attente et c'est très confus pour les usagers. Comme c'est le premier contact avec Ti-billet, c'est assez démotivant pour les usagers.
comments:
Bonne idée pour moi.
Ayant fait de nombreuses fois l'acceuil dans plusieurs lieux avec TiBillet, je comprend ce que tu veux dire.
Néanmoins, ça ne me génait pas. J'en profitais souvent pour discuter et expliquer ce qu'est l'outil. Charger la carte et faire payer l'adhésion prenait moins de temps a faire qu'a expliquer :)

@filaos974 T'en pense quoi ?
Si on améliore le design des catégories d'articles par méthode, ça peut passer ?
On peut mettre l'adhésion et la recharge dans le même groupe ? A priori c'est les mêmes actions.

Mettre par contre un article vente, ça va être un peu plus coton.
Le comportement du lecteur de carte cashless n'est pas du tout le même.

title: Enatega Customer Application: Ratings or reviews percentage calculation issue
description:
**Describe the bug**
The calculated percentage for ratings or reviews is incorrect. For example, the displayed percentage does not align with the actual number of reviews or ratings provided by users, leading to misleading information about the product/service’s quality.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Go to 'Enatega Customer Application'
2. Click on any restaurant card details , card will open up.
3. Now click on See Reviews button , all the reviews will show up now see that total reviews are 41 but only showing the 17% of it
4. See error

**Expected behavior**
The ratings or reviews percentage should accurately reflect the proportion of users who rated the product/service within the specified range (e.g., 4 stars or higher).

**Screenshots**

**Smartphone (please complete the following information):**

- Device: [e.g. Infinix Hot 50]
- OS: [e.g. Android]
- Browser [e.g. Application]
- Version [e.g. Latest]

title: [META] ARM, mobile/embedded devices, and IBM POWER ppc64le
description:
GStreamer has encoders and screen capturing interfaces from various embedded operating systems, including Raspberry Pi and NVIDIA Jetson. [gst-omx](https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/gstreamer/gstreamer/-/tree/main/subprojects/gst-omx) is an example of an encoder usable for Raspberry Pi and other ARM SoCs. `v4l2codecs` in gst-bad enables encoding support for Video4Linux as well.
While support for Android or iOS is probably out of our scope, ARM Linux support should be useful.

Relevant files: https://github.com/selkies-project/selkies-gstreamer/blob/master/src/selkies_gstreamer/gstwebrtc_app.py and to add `omxh264enc` and/or `v4l2h264enc`, then to add `aarch64` capabilities to GStreamer build workflows.

**The most critical part here is the native build pipeline (emulation is prohibited because of a 7-8x overhead and 6-hour time limit for GitHub Actions).**
comments: https://github.com/m1k1o/neko uses `v4l2h264enc` for Raspberry Pi.

@ndufresne, maintainer of the v4l2 plugin of GStreamer Good Plugins:

```
yeah, so I'd say, stick with VP8/H264 (and HEVC perhaps)
I've seen some activity (of VP9 encoders) on Exynos side, after half a decade of silence, might be good news
as for stateless/rk (Rockchip), I expect one or two more years before that is ready
Media CODEC in Linux are still in catchup mode
```

VP9 encoders are out of the table for at least a year. Thus, I am focusing on H.264 and VP8, with H.265 to be back on the table if we land WebTransport.

https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/gstreamer/gst-plugins-good/-/commit/040e25218ac4d7cf50bcfd4651300b4bdfa629cb

From https://github.com/selkies-project/docker-nvidia-egl-desktop/issues/23: @brianlmerritt

NVIDIA Jetson:

1. Compiling GStreamer for AARCH64 (addons/gstreamer)
2. Add nvv4l2h264enc/nvv4l2vp9enc and test
3. Verify all the pipeline works
Would be trivial for newbies.

https://docs.nvidia.com/jetson/archives/r35.2.1/DeveloperGuide/text/SD/Multimedia/AcceleratedGstreamer.html

Nicholas Dufresne (ndufresne) at #gstreamer IRC oftc.net should be experienced in this regard.
GST-OMX is deprecated. Stick with v4l2.

https://github.blog/changelog/2025-01-16-linux-arm64-hosted-runners-now-available-for-free-in-public-repositories-public-preview/

This will finally pave the way.

title: Nit: Add PR url to LAND_STACK_TIP
description:
# Summary
Curious if you would be open to it. I often create a PR or a stack of PRs and have a hard finding the stack of URls. Would you be open to adding this or making it an option/ configurable?
comments: Yeah, that would be a nice change! It does print it in the logs (at least if `--verbose` is set), but having it printed in a summary at the end would be helpful. Please feel free to send a PR if you're up to it :)

As a workaround, if your terminal supports the [terminal hyperlinks spec](https://gist.github.com/egmontkob/eb114294efbcd5adb1944c9f3cb5feda) (a lot of them do), running `stack-pr view` after you create the stack will give you clickable links.

title: Add regular std::span support to spanbufs
description:
In particular, accepting std::span as inputs on constructor.  Likely behind the scenes this gets converted to and estd::span.

Future code may consider aliasing std:;span to estd::span and/or doing an Impl pattern on the spanbuf to switch to std::span or estd::span specifically.  Perhaps take a stab at some of that in this issue.

title: Additional Stopping Criteria for internal FEDDLIB Newton Solver
description:
Nonlinear Criteria In feddlib/problems/Solver/NonLinearSolver_def.hpp 
  - Inside solveNewton/ solveFixedPoint (internal nonlinear solver routines) there are currently only two options for the stopping criteria available 
    i) Residuum (relative) ||F(x_k+1)||/||F(x_0)|| 
    ii) Update (absolute)  || x_k+1 - x_k|| 

    TODO: Add other options (equivalent to Options in NOX) like Residuum (absolute) ||F(x_k+1) - F(x_k)|| or Update (relative) and combinations

title: Add isEnglishWord API route and function
comments:
Hi @drewg2009,

I would love to implement the isEnglishWord API route and function!
Awesome sounds great @bryan-melo!

Awesome! 

There are many ways I can approach this. A quick and easy way would be to make an API call to a Dictionary API or WordsAPI to check if a word is part of an english dictionary. However, the trade-offs are that it would reliant on that API and would require an internet connection.

I could also use the spellchecker library in Node.js. This would be great for offline usage and wouldn't have any external dependencies. However, the trade-off is that this library only checks for spelling and not whether a word is truly English. 

A third approach could be to use REGEX to check if the word contains English alphabet characters. However, this could lead to many false positives, as it wouldn't verify whether the word is actually English.

Let me know if you like any of these approaches or If you'd like me to research alternatives.

Thanks!

I am perfectly okay with using a Words or Dictionary API that has no costs associated. 

It would be the most accurate as words change overtime. 

The API is served over an internet connection anyway so I think that is fine as a dependency. 

We also may want to consider caching results for faster responses, but we can do that as a part of the caching issue

title: [Painpoint] Use `reviewed-by` query for more accurate review queries
description:
### Context

Users who get reports regularly find the report misses some reviews that were performed.

### Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Update the query for reviews within `queries.ts` > `prContributionsQuery` to use `reviewed-by` instead of `involves`
- [ ] Rename the query to `prReviewsQuery` (https://github.com/inkblotty/my-work-action/issues/51 will handle updating contributions to others' work)
- [ ] Update the tests related to the previous changes

title: Migrate to Swift Testing from XCTest
description:
### Problem

With [Swift Testing](https://github.com/swiftlang/swift-testing) being added to the Swift 6 toolchain and the published images & Xcode already containing it, we should migrate all of our packages towards the modern Swift Testing framework.

### Solution

All unit tests and should migrate from `XCTest` to the new [Swift Testing framework](https://developer.apple.com/xcode/swift-testing/) included in the Swift 6 toolchain. We can follow the documentation article to [migrating a test from XCTest](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/testing/migratingfromxctest).

Contributes working on this issue should first watch the swift-testing WWDC videos:
- [Meet Swift Testing](https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2024/10179)
- [Go further with Swift Testing](https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2024/10195)

We should take advantage of [test suites](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/testing/organizingtests), [parameterized tests](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/testing/parameterizedtesting), and [parallel testing and optimizing our test suites](https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2024/10195?time=1269).

### Additional context

_No response_

### Code of Conduct

- [x] I agree to follow this project's Code of Conduct and Contributing Guidelines

title: Linking to the Github and update warnings
description: It would probably be useful to provide a direct link to Github from the help tab so users can report issues quicker. And with that, it might also be good for the mod manager to make checks for the latest releases to inform its users of new updates.
comments: I'll implement the first half of this in 0.5.0, but the rest of it will happen in a later version. Specifically, it'll check if there's a new version of the mod available on the workshop by checking last updated dates. Additionally, I'll keep mod info in the modlist for mods that are no longer available, however it will be indicated in the UI they're no longer available on the workshop.
A "Bugreport" button has been added to the help menu.

Unit Tests for HuggingFace Model Integration and /predict Endpoint Functionality
description:
Create and execute unit tests for the app.py file to verify the integration of the HuggingFace model and the /predict endpoint functionality.

Acceptance Criteria :
- A unit test confirms that the HuggingFace model is loaded successfully and processes input correctly.
- A test validates that the /predict endpoint handles valid input and returns a proper response.
- A test ensures that the application assigns a free port dynamically and within the valid port range.
- Ensure that all tests pass without errors when executed.

Expected Behavior:
- When a valid input is sent to the /predict endpoint, the API should return a successful response with the generated text.

title: 512 bytes limit for png and gif on new 32x32 panel from Ali Express
description:
Hello

I have a problem with a new 32x32 panel I bought from AliExpress:

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1005006130862334.html?spm=a2g0o.order_list.order_list_main.29.6c191802RhNszc

For some reason only png and gif files that are smaller than 512 bytes work on it. If I send bigger png's then I get black screen, if I send bigger gif animations then it goes directly to the default animations on the device. Don't know what to do but as soon as the file is bigger than 512 bytes I can't send anything. Clocks, countdowns, score panel, etc. all work fine.

Note: All animations from the iDotMatrix app and everything there works fine, so there is a problem somewhere else when sending data, I think.

Also I can import the same gif animations from photos to the iDotMatrix APP and it will display them perfectly, so definetly not a size problem on the device. But it is such a shitty APP ... I would love to be able to just use my rPI and send the gif's to the device in random order with a simple bash script.
comments: Note: tried chaning the  png_chunks = self._splitIntoChunks(png_data, 4096)   4096 to 512 or 256 and I got the same result... no difference

I did a build on Windows, just to see if there is something wrong with my rPi3 build and I get the same problem - as soon as the PNG/GIF is bigger than 512 bytes it doesn't want to upload. But on windows I get an actual error when using bigger files than 512:

11.10.2024 02:04:36 :: DEBUG :: idotmatrix.connectionManager :: sending message(s) to device
11.10.2024 02:04:36 :: ERROR :: idotmatrix.modules.image :: could not upload the unprocessed image: [WinError -2147024809] The parameter is incorrect

More investigation... In the method _createPayloads   as soon as the whole payload that is created extends 512 bytes I get the error. 
Is there a possibility to get the info of the reverse engineering of how the payload is sent ? Was reverse engineering done on the code or on the actual BT data that was sent to the device?

Found a github repository https://github.com/8none1/idotmatrix
It has a working implementation of GIF and image upload that works with ANY file size (even bigger than 4096) ... 
so if anyone wants to bug fix this repository then check it out. I haven't had time to actually check it yet.

Won't be closing this issue until someone fixes it.
Hi @TomCat666 you're right. This still is an ongoing issue. However, I am still not able to work as much for this project as I wanted to. I'll mark your issue and will look into it :)

only difference I can see from what https://github.com/8none1/idotmatrix generated is in the size field of the headers
 
field "total payload size inc headers over all chunks " for the example 18 animated gif (raw gif size is 5599 bytes 0x15df https://github.com/8none1/idotmatrix/blob/main/assets_test/downloads/NEWGIFS2/18.GIF) 

eg chunk0  "ff 15 00 00"  while this library uses "ef 15 00 00"

```diff
diff idotmatrix_controller.log python3-idotmatrix.log 
2c2
< 1010010000ff1500009c841fd505000d
---
> 1010010000ef1500009c841fd505000d
261c261
< ef05010002ff1500009c841fd505000d
---
> ef05010002ef1500009c841fd505000d

```

Here are the logs (formatted into 16 byte lines)
[logs.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/17522414/logs.zip)

But I cant make either upload this 18.GIF

Ill re-enable bluetooth logging and see the app is doing  (in a few days, if I get time)
Typical. I upload the example 18.gif to my phone and sent it to the idotmatrix, and guess what it doesn't display via the app either!!  (yes its 32x32 which matches my device)

@ellensp I have committed some updates to the idotmatrix-libary as well as bumping the library version in this repository. Simply run "create_venv.sh" again and check if it is working now. There is some upper timeout for GIFs. Maybe someone can figure this out. At least my bigger demo gifs with around 6 to 8kb are working now.

Please see also issue #32 which also is about gifs not working correctly.
Update: seems it still works unreliable. Worked even after reboot and now it isn't working properly anmore. Damn china stuff :D

Doesn't seem to work at all here for GIF's bigger than 512 bytes still.... 
Yea, china stuff ... its cheap, but then you get this :) 

I got the other library working nicely now though. The author added the reset (delete) command which I need to call every 20 or so gif uploads so the device is reset (only takes a fraction of a second). If I don't do that then it looses connection after a while (china stuff :) ). Now it is running non-stop 24/7 without any hiccups.
@TomCat666 okay, I will look into this again :) should be fixable. No idea currently what exactly the problem is though.
can you provide a example or two that never works

A few that never work here:
![SoldierAll](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/beb13043-9adc-4019-acb6-084852026e0f)
![boy](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8118ef99-57b4-4fe5-a92d-aa57a66bb59a)
![FoxWalk](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/04c88252-44b6-4eaf-81cd-87e45f29e77a)

All 3 examples provided uploaded to my 32x32 iDotMatrix display without issues using the python3-idotmatrix-client

Ie the following commands all worked fine. (your address will be different) 
python app.py --address 0E:81:B3:86:B3:54 --set-gif ~/Downloads/382560499-04c88252-44b6-4eaf-81cd-87e45f29e77a.gif
python app.py --address 0E:81:B3:86:B3:54 --set-gif ~/Downloads/382560492-8118ef99-57b4-4fe5-a92d-aa57a66bb59a.gif
python app.py --address 0E:81:B3:86:B3:54 --set-gif ~/Downloads/382560475-beb13043-9adc-4019-acb6-084852026e0f.gif

Make sure you updated the idotmatrix library to 0.0.7
Eg im using venv, a pip list on my machine
 
```
(venv) :~/Downloads/iDotMatrix/python3-idotmatrix-client$ pip list
Package                   Version
------------------------- -------
altgraph                  0.17.4
asyncio                   3.4.3
bleak                     0.22.3
cffi                      1.17.1
cryptography              43.0.3
dbus-fast                 2.24.3
idotmatrix                0.0.7            <-------------------------------- make sure yours says 0.0.7
packaging                 24.1
pillow                    11.0.0
pip                       24.0
pycparser                 2.22
pyinstaller               6.11.0
pyinstaller-hooks-contrib 2024.9
PyQt5                     5.15.11
PyQt5-Qt5                 5.15.15
PyQt5_sip                 12.15.0
setuptools                75.2.0

```
Ahh, that was it. After updating it is working now. Thank you !

Hi. gifs are working fine in 0.0.7, but I have a problem with PNGs. no matter what, only PNG I got working was demo_32.png - yellow duck. I tried upload.Processed and uploadUnprocessed. demo_16.png does come trhough to the display but only if sent Unprocessed, and it comes scrambled - image unusable, just trying to think of the reason for this behavior. 

I did not get working any of my own PNGs, no matter how resized, resampled, stripped of alpha, etc, none worked. Filesize is no indicator too, as demo_16 is pretty smal and it still fails. Does anybody have any idea? my files:


```shell
-rw-r--r-- 1 pi pi 1.3K Jun 21  2019 ./images/10n.png
-rw-r--r-- 1 pi pi  734 Nov 19 23:39 ./images/10n_r.png
-rw-r--r-- 1 pi pi  259 Nov 19 23:19 ./images/demo_16.png
-rw-r--r-- 1 pi pi  430 Nov 19 23:19 ./images/demo_32.png
-rw-r--r-- 1 pi pi 1.4K Nov 19 23:19 ./images/demo_512.png
-rw-r--r-- 1 pi pi  520 Nov 19 23:19 ./images/demo_64.png
``` 

error is still the same:  
`ERROR :: idotmatrix.modules.image :: could not upload processed image: [org.bluez.Error.Failed] Failed to initiate write`

After patching the client to accept a command line that made sense 

```diff
diff --git a/core/cmd.py b/core/cmd.py
index aad3381..0b1086d 100644
--- a/core/cmd.py
+++ b/core/cmd.py
@@ -520,15 +520,15 @@ class CMD:
             await image.setMode(
                 mode=1,
             )
-            if args.set_image:
+            if args.image:
                 if args.process_image:
                     await image.uploadProcessed(
-                        file_path=args.set_image,
+                        file_path=args.image,
                         pixel_size=int(args.process_image),
                     )
                 else:
                     await image.uploadUnprocessed(
-                        file_path=args.set_image,
+                        file_path=args.image,
                     )
 
     async def gif(self, args):
```

produces 439 bytes of data to send.

The library needs to transmit smaller blocks 

in https://github.com/derkalle4/python3-idotmatrix-library/blob/main/idotmatrix/modules/image.py#L123

replace line 123    
```
await self.conn.send(data=data)
``` 
 with

```python
                    chunks = self._splitIntoChunks(data, 512)
                    for chunk in chunks:
                        await self.conn.send(data=chunk)
```

so far its worked on every test image I've done, up scaling from 16x16 though is a blur and not very nice  

After other have confirmed this works, will formalize a PR to get this corrected

title: Chat messages dissapearing
description:
**Describe the bug**
After sending/receiving the same message, I get a lag spike and they both dissapear

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Join a server
2. Send an identical message
3. See bug

**Expected behavior**
A lag spike for around 0.5-1 seconds, then chat messages dissapearing

**Client information**
 - OS: macOS: Sonoma 14.1.1
 - Minecraft: Fabric 1.20.4

title: Disable second launcher item

With those, I am hoping to add your little app. But the second icon in my launcher irritates me. Can this be disabled via the app settings? It does not matter which of the two but I only need one. Thank you for your consideration.
comments:
This has been similarly requested and discussed here: https://github.com/felixwiemuth/SimpleReminder/discussions/15#discussioncomment-9017075

I am considering adding it as an option. It is not straight-forward to implement but there is a workaround which is not too complicated: https://medium.com/@callmeryan/changing-the-android-app-icon-programmatically-c913550330d

title: Add RJMP and RCALL as aliases for JMP and CALL
description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
When taking assembly files, usually compilers/people use RJMP and RCALL when they're not jumping far. We don't have these instructions and therefore the parser will reject them.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Since all our branch and jump instructions function on the same technique (i.e. jumping to a relative position to the PC), there is no architecture change needed. They will function exactly as their non-relative cousins, JMP and CALL, just with different names. In an actual pocessor, they would be implemented differently, since JMP holds the address to jump to as an immediate value instead of a relative address. Ours don't. But it doesn't make any difference from the perspective of the programmer, behaviour-wise. 

So what I propose is to add parsers for RJMP and RCALL that will return JMP and CALL instructions instead, therefore eliminating the issue. Nothing else needs to be changed, since JMP and CALL are already implemented.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I debated whether to overhaul the jump mechanism, and we will probably do that in the future, but for now, this works fine and has the same result. 

**Additional context**
Don't forget to add the new instructions to the README.md and make tests for these new instructions. You can more or less just copy the already made test files for CALL and JMP and modify them to use RCALL and RJMP, and they should behave the same. If there are any questions, leave them here as comments. 

Also, please leave a comment if you want to work on this.

title: Add support  for training on Google's ARCO ERA5
description:
## Detailed Description
The Google ERA5 archive is available: https://github.com/google-research/ARCO-ERA5 and goes back quite far. Its currently being expanded, but already covers years of data at the native model resolution. This is probably quicker and faster to pull data from than HuggingFace, and is already on Google Public Datasets, so should be easy to integrate. 

## Context
Its a lot of data in an accessible and publicly available place that we can try to leverage for training the graph models easily.

## Possible Implementation
A HuggingFace dataset script like for the EUMETSAT data? Or can just add Xarray opening it in this repo directly as well.
comments: The  HuggingFace datasets script will be hosted  here https://huggingface.co/datasets/openclimatefix/arco-era5
Hi, is this issue available to work on?
Yes, I believe so, I can assign you it?
Yes, that sounds good!
@jacobbieker could you assign to me?
@FilippoContessa yeah, I'd recommend doing this one or the other issue, which would you prefer? I can always assign you to the other one after the first one is done?

title: Update danube-admin-cli to support creation of topics with reliable dispatch
description:
Collecting workspace information

## Description

The `danube-admin-cli` currently does not support creating topics with reliable dispatch. This feature is essential for ensuring message persistence and durability. This story aims to add support for creating reliable dispatch topics in the `danube-admin-cli`.

## Steps to Implement

* [ ] Update [TopicsCommands](https://github.com/danrusei/danube/blob/main/danube-admin-cli/src/topics.rs#L14) Enum to include an option for creating reliable dispatch topics.
* [ ] Update the [handle_command](https://github.com/danrusei/danube/blob/main/danube-admin-cli/src/topics.rs#L51) function  accordingly
* [ ] Update [NewTopicRequest](https://github.com/danrusei/danube/blob/main/proto/DanubeAdmin.proto#L41) message from the proto file
* [ ] Update [DanubeAdminImpl](https://github.com/danrusei/danube/blob/main/danube-broker/src/admin/topics_admin.rs#L13) to handle the new dispatch strategy format.
* [ ] Update testing and documentation if applicable

title: Configuration page: UCC additional property error
description:
Hi Livehybrid,

thanks a lot for your app. I just wanted to to give it a try, but I cannot get past an error on the configuration page.

The error appears every time in the same fashion. I first installed v1.1.4 from splunkbase on a splunk 9.3.0. Then I upgraded to v1.1.7 from github and then splunk to 9.3.2.

Everytime when trying to load the configuration page the following error appears and the page is not loaded correctly:
`Internal configuration file error. Something wrong within the package or installation step. Contact your administrator for support. Detail: instance.meta is not allowed to have the additional property "_uccVersion"`

When removing the line "_uccVersion": "5.49.0" from /appserver/static/js/build/globalConfig.json (and _bump'ing or restarting), the error changes into:
`Internal configuration file error. Something wrong within the package or installation step. Contact your administrator for support. Detail: configuration file not found`

What could be done to fix or workaround this UCC error?
comments:
@Bamfax this issue should be resolved in the latest release, however Tesla is also shutting down the existing API and replacing with their Fleet API which has a much more complicated setup process.
We are currently beta testing an updated app with some users with updates to consume from the fleet API and will update here when it is generally available.

I used the v1.2.0 release and the configuration page is accessible and working now. thank you very much  @livehybrid.
Trying to get it set up I struggled a bit, but will post that seperately.

title: Difference in GitHub and Gitlab version ranges
description:
github and gitlab both provide different VulnerableRange format for Maven, While Github provides something like this `>= 2.13.0, < 2.16.0` , Gitlab provides something like this `(,1.7]` 
Other than that, our current GemVersionRange fails for the Gitlab format of gem vulnerableRanges `>=3.0.0 <4.2.11.1||>=5.0.0 <5.0.7.2||>=5.1.0 <5.1.6.2||>=5.2.0 <5.2.2.1` , but it works fine with GitHub version Ranges

title: Add Team Members' Names to "About Pluna" Section
description:
Description
I would like to propose adding our team members' names to the "About Pluna" section of the website.

Reasons for the Suggestion:
Recognition: Highlighting the contributors to the Pluna project can boost team morale and recognize everyone's efforts.
Transparency: Showing team member information provides transparency about who is behind the project.

Professionalism: This addition could make the website feel more professional and complete.

Proposal
Update the "About Pluna" section to include a list of team members' names.
Format the names in a visually appealing way that aligns with the website's theme.
Optionally, add roles or contributions for each team member if appropriate.

Expected Benefits
Strengthen the sense of community and collaboration within the team.
Improve the professional image of the website.
Acknowledge the contributions of each team member.
comments: Great suggestion! Recognizing team members in the "About Pluna" section can definitely enhance transparency and professionalism. Let’s also consider team members’ privacy preferences before moving forward. I’m happy to support this if we decide to implement it!

Great suggestion! Adding team members to the "About Pluna" section would indeed enhance transparency and professionalism. However, as the number of contributors grows, it might become challenging to maintain and update this list consistently on the website. Would it be better to include this information on the GitHub repository instead? This way, we could keep the contributor details dynamically updated and focused on the development team while maintaining the simplicity of the website. What do you think?

Thank you for your thoughtful suggestion! Adding the team members' names to the "About Pluna" section is a great idea. It will not only give well-deserved recognition to contributors but also enhance the transparency and professionalism of our website. However, it can make it difficult to select members without us by increasing contributors. I think it would be better to share opinions in more depth.

title: enlarge(/boost/magnify/increase)   youtube's volume slider
description:
<!--
(Click PREVIEW to undestand this template) 
               OPTIONALLY fill the table if each point fits in the same line: 
-->

⚬ _PROBLEM_: 
I'm frustrated by the inability to boost volume on videos. The Forced Volume option under Player has the strange behavior of setting all volume controls on newly opened YouTube videos to maximum, then, I guess, some volume amplification is done in the background.  

⚬ _SOLUTION_:    
The behavior I expect is to have the volume slider on newly opened players be where I set it last, and to have the volume boost added to that level, not to set the slider to maximum, then amp up the volume from there.

 ⚬ _RELEVANCE / SCOPE_: 
I claim this affects all users.

⚬ _"SIDE EFFECTS"_:   
No conflicts.

⚬ _CONTEXT_:       <!-- any other context. -->
 Thank  you!

SHORT Table | (Summary)     
------------ | -------------   
*Problem*     |            Unexpected behavior from the Forced Volume option                        
*Solution*     |             Change behavior to not automatically set a new player's volume slider to 100%                                     
*Alternatives*|         
*Scope*         |           
*Side effects*|        
*Context*      |              Every newly opened video player
comments:
Would you feel better if the slider still displayed whatever volume you have set now while video played louder? What purpose would the slider at lets say for example 30% have in that case? 

Lower volume sound samples carry less data. Yes, its possible to leave volume low and apply gain on that low volume signal, but it will sound terrible.

I’m going to say:
1. if the player volume slider is set to 100, the plug-in should play the audio at 200%—I don’t know if this is possible, I’m just setting up a scenario
2. If the plug-in is set to automatically amplify audio, and the YouTube player is set to 50%, I would expect the output to be 100%.
3. If the plug-in is set to automatically amplify audio, and the YouTube player is set to 30%, I would expect the output to be around 70%.

I work in UX, but haven’t worked on this specific situation before. I also don’t know, from a technical standpoint, how your plug-in—for which I thank the stars every day I use it—works with audio.

> On Mar 25, 2024, at 1:19 AM, Rasz_pl ***@***.***> wrote:
> 
> 
> Would you feel better if the slider still displayed whatever volume you have set now while video played louder? What purpose would the slider at lets say for example 30% have in that case?
> 
> Lover volume sound samples carry less data. Yes, its possible to leave volume low and apply gain on that low volume signal, but it will sound terrible.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <https://github.com/code-charity/youtube/issues/2116#issuecomment-2017305412>, or unsubscribe <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ACUUL3PFDWHQKGJRC6DWIDLYZ66XBAVCNFSM6AAAAABFE2UM6CVHI2DSMVQWIX3LMV43OSLTON2WKQ3PNVWWK3TUHMZDAMJXGMYDKNBRGI>.
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
>

Took me a good couple of days, buy I got there eventually!
I finally understand what you are talking about, a general "boost my crappy speakers by x" software toggle. Pretend the new 150% volume is just 30% etc.
Instead of 0-400% "Forced volume" we can let User directly set separate "Volume Gain" multiplier and figure out logistics under the hood by faking YT player volume slider reading and switching between no gain and gain at appropriate levels. Yes, this makes sense and is much more user friendly.

The way it currently works is anything up to 100% is pure volume, above we use AudioContext createGain()
https://github.com/code-charity/youtube/blob/f935ebf554aaa735b092d9a1cf01e72a1b09a7d0/js%26css/web-accessible/www.youtube.com/player.js#L530-L548

title: Read only part 2
description: It would be nice to have a flag for reading only part 2 of a puzzle.
comments:
The underlying [aoc-cli](https://github.com/scarvalhojr/aoc-cli) does not have a flag for it. It should be simple enough to add this on our side, but I'm wondering if the upstream project wouldn't benefit from this as well.

Anyway, I would accept a PR that adds this on our side as well.

Something I noticed is that once you have completed part 1, the part 2 is not saved automatically to the puzzle file. Doing `cargo read <problem_no>` after you have completed part 1 makes use of the aoc website/api and reads the puzzle from there but after that it does not save it to the puzzles file again. The puzzle file stays outdated

I opened an issue for tracking this request https://github.com/scarvalhojr/aoc-cli/issues/27.
I'm not entirely sure if the author will get around to reviewing it since it looks like the other PRs from a year ago haven't gotten any updates, but I suppose we'll see if that changes. 🤞

I just create a PR for this in the `aoc-cli` crate https://github.com/scarvalhojr/aoc-cli/pull/28. I'm not sure when it'll get reviewed, but if someone wants this feature immediately, I can open a PR here. :P
Oh nice, hope this gets merged soon. I would accept a PR that adds it here if there is interest.

title: Generic Type Problem
comments:
Hi @Esatyilmaz0, first of all thanks for opening this issue! I personally knew I'd have to deal with `Generic` type classes at some point, so in any case I'm glad as this is the first issue that actually addresses that. I'll have to dig a big deeper into `typing.Generic` to understand exactly how it works, as I'm not too familiar with it myself.

The main points that are worth asking here would probably be something along the lines of:
- How does one identify that a class or a dataclass is a `typing.Generic` type
- What is the best approach to get the Generic type argument out of a class

Notes on the above: I have a feeling that the builtin `typing.get_type_hints` might be able to resolve the type of fields given a dataclass that extends from `Generic[T]`, but haven't looked too closely into it yet.

---

In the meantime, I would certainly encourage you to check out the Contributing docs if you are interested in adding your own changes. As mentioned, I'm going to dig a bit deeper to understand how `typing.Generic` works exactly, which honestly might end up taking me some time.

I believe I'm running into the same issue using a Generic to define a JSONWizard dataclass. I've created a simple case with a User that can take a generic type to used for a user's name. 

The first two examples work fine when the main class is a generic dataclass. To json and from json both work as expected. The problem seems to happen when I try to use the working dataclass as a type in another dataclass. Serialization works but deserialization doesn't.

Works..
```
from dataclasses import dataclass
from typing import Generic, TypeVar

from dataclass_wizard import JSONWizard  # type:ignore

T = TypeVar("T")


@dataclass
class User(Generic[T], JSONWizard):
    name: T


@dataclass
class Name:
    first: str
    last: str

# User.name is a Name
user_one = User[Name](Name("billy", "joel"))
# user_one -> User(name=Name(first='billy', last='joel'))
with open("temp_one.json", "w") as f:
    f.write(user_one.to_json())
# temp_one.json -> {"name": {"first": "billy", "last": "joel"}}
with open("temp_one.json", "r") as f:
    imported_user_one = User.from_json(f.read())
# imported_user_one -> User(name={'first': 'billy', 'last': 'joel'})

# User.name is now a string
user_two = User[str]("frank")
# user_two -> User(name='frank')
with open("temp_two.json", "w") as f:
    f.write(user_two.to_json())
# temp_two.json -> {"name": "frank"}

with open("temp_two.json", "r") as f:
    imported_user_two = User.from_json(f.read())
# imported_user_two -> User(name='frank')
```

The following does not work though:
```
@dataclass
class NamedUser(JSONWizard):
    user: User[Name]


user_three = NamedUser(User(Name("frank", "zappa")))
with open("temp_three.json", "w") as f:
    f.write(user_three.to_json())
# temp_three.json -> {"user": {"name": {"first": "frank", "last": "zappa"}}}
with open("temp_three.json", "r") as f:
    imported_user_three = NamedUser.from_json(f.read())
# ParseError: Failure parsing field `None` in class `None`. Expected a type User, got NoneType.
#   value: None
#   error: Provided type is not currently supported.
#   unsupported_type: <class '__main__.User'>
```

Full stack trace:
```

---> 14     imported_user_three = NamedUser.from_json(f.read())

---> 48         return fromdict(cls, o) if isinstance(o, dict) else fromlist(cls, o)

~/anaconda3/lib/python3.8/site-packages/dataclass_wizard/loaders.py in fromdict(cls, d)

--> 534         load = load_func_for_dataclass(cls)

~/anaconda3/lib/python3.8/site-packages/dataclass_wizard/loaders.py in load_func_for_dataclass(cls, is_main_class, config)

--> 581     field_to_parser = dataclass_field_to_load_parser(cls_loader, cls, config)
